programs.description: A large subset of input genes coordinate replication origin licensing, replication fork progression, DNA synthesis, and chromatin assembly in glioblastoma. Overexpression of licensing factors (MCMs, CDC45, GINS1, MCM10, WDHD1, POLA1/2, POLE2, PRIM2, RRM2, LIG1, ASF1B, CHAF1A/B) accelerates S-phase entry and increases replication fork speed. These changes support unchecked proliferation in glioblastoma, often at the cost of increased replication stress, genomic instability, and therapeutic resistance.

citation.notes: MCM2-7 loading at origins, CDC45 and GINS1 activation, replication origins in glioma and cancer
Rapid licensing and fork progression in stem/progenitor cells
CAF-1 CHAF1A/CHAF1B, ASF1B as histone chaperones mediate assembly of replication-dependent chromatin
CMG helicase formation with MCM2-7, CDC45, GINS1

predicted_cellular_impact: Accelerated S-phase entry and DNA replication
Increased replication stress and genome instability
Support for high proliferation rate in malignant glioblastoma
programs.evidence_summary: Strong enrichment for replication licensing components; S-phase genes strongly co-expressed and upregulated in glioma and GBM. Knockdown and inhibition studies show impairment of proliferation and increased sensitivity to chemotherapy.

citations.notes: Fundamental role and overexpression of licensing genes in cancer, including glioma.
Essential for licensing, not present in input signature

programs.program_name: Homologous Recombination and DNA Damage Response
programs.description: Coordinated function of FANCD2, FANCA, FANCI, RAD51AP1, RAD54L, XRCC2, BRCA1, BRCA2, EXO1, BRIP1, RAD18 and CHEK1 supports double-strand break repair via homologous recombination and Fanconi anemia pathway, contributing to DNA repair proficiency and chemo- and radioresistance in GBM. These programs enable DNA repair of oncogene-induced damage from rapid proliferation, protecting viability while reinforcing treatment resistance.

citation.notes: RAD51AP1, RAD54L, XRCC2, BRCA1/2 functionally cooperate in HR
Fanconi anemia components function in DNA interstrand crosslink repair, frequently dysregulated in glioma
CHEK1, CLSPN, ATR act in replication stress checkpoint, prevent S-phase progression under DNA damage
RAD51AP1, RAD54L foci formation after DNA damage

predicted_cellular_impact: Enhanced DNA repair and tolerance to replication stress
Increased resistance to genotoxic chemotherapy and radiotherapy
Maintenance of genomic integrity under oncogenic stress
programs.evidence_summary: Comprehensive HR and damage-response machinery is present; these components correlate with radio/chemo resistance in GBM and poor patient outcome when overactive.

citations.notes: Summary of RAD51AP1, HR repair, and roles in glioblastoma
Full checkpoint machinery required, some essential kinases not in input

programs.description: Aurora B kinase, PLK4, ESPL1, KIF15, KIF24, SPC24, SPC25, CENPU, CENPI, CENPK, CENPP, SKA3, KNTC1, AURKB, VRK1 coordinate mitotic spindle assembly, kinetochore formation, chromosome alignment, separation and cytokinesis in glioblastoma. Overexpression or mutation of these mitosis regulators is common in high-grade glioma, contributing to polyploidy/aneuploidy, rapid cell cycling, and treatment resistance.

citation.notes: MASTL kinase regulates entry into mitosis and chromosome condensation
Centromere and kinetochore proteins assemble at CENP-A/Nucleosome
KIF15 controls spindle formation and separation, influences proliferation in glioblastoma
KIF15, kinesin family members create spindle architecture

predicted_cellular_impact: Promotion of cell division and rapid proliferation
programs.evidence_summary: High expression of mitosis/spindle/kinetochore regulators is common in glioma, linked to increased malignancy and poor prognosis.

citations.notes: Aurora B correlates with aggressive behavior in GBM
Primary kinetochore formation depends on CENP-A, mitotic checkpoint on BUB1/MAD2

programs.description: E2F family (E2F1, E2F7), FOXM1, MYBL2 (B-MYB), CCNE2, TCF19, PBK, and related genes form a transcriptional program that activates entry into S-phase and G2/M progression in glioblastoma. They coordinate expression of DNA replication, mitosis, and checkpoint genes and mediate adaptation to oncogenic signals. FOXM1 and E2Fs drive cell cycle gene expression and promote proliferation, invasion, stemness, and drug resistance in GBM.

citation.notes: E2F1/E2F7 regulate S-phase entry and progression
FOXM1 regulates mitotic genes for cell division and invasion in glioblastoma

predicted_cellular_impact: Upregulated expression of replication and mitosis genes
Increased invasion, stemness, and poor prognosis
programs.evidence_summary: High FOXM1, E2F1, MYBL2 activity in GBM; signature correlates with proliferation, radioresistance, and poor clinical outcome.

citations.notes: MYBL2 and FOXM1 promote glioma progression
Cell cycle transcriptional program includes other factors not in input

programs.description: UHRF1, HELLS, ATAD2, ASF1B, CHAF1A/CHAF1B, MNBL3, DNA2 and others participate in chromatin remodeling, DNA methylation, and histone modification in glioblastoma. These processes regulate gene expression, facilitate cell cycle progression, and contribute to treatment resistance and cellular adaptation.

citation.notes: MGMT, UHRF1 roles in methylation status and treatment response in glioblastoma
ATAD2-dependent transcriptional regulation modulates proliferation and radioresistance
CAF-1 complex and ASF1B facilitate nucleosome formation post-replication

predicted_cellular_impact: Epigenetic silencing of tumor suppressors and altered gene expression
Increased proliferation and resistance to therapy
Enhanced adaptability and stemness in glioblastoma
programs.evidence_summary: Epigenetic regulators enable DNA methylation and chromatin changes seen in GBM. These alterations underpin cancer adapation, stemness, and drug resistance.

citations.notes: ATAD2 transcriptional activity promotes tumorigenesis and resistance in GBM
Prominent methylation regulators are MGMT, DNMT1, not present in list

method.notes: Programs identified using manual and automated literature synthesis and pathway clustering, cross-validated with cancer genomics/GBM datasets.
